body:
More specifics on sampling and getting useful data out of redash:

The `longitudinal` dataset rolls a lot of things up for you (each row contains a unique client ID and all the rest of the data is present as arrays on each row) and makes this easier although due to the size of the data you still must take a sample. The larger problem is that it is only updated once per week.

To get data closer to real time, there is a `main summary` dataset that is updated more often (close to real-time IIRC), but as the data hasn't been rolled up as above it's a huge number of rows so you must take a very tiny sample to keep from melting the infra.

I have less experience with ATMO but my understanding is that you must write a map/reduce job or a Jupyter notebook and have that job run regularly.

There's also a tool called Hindsight that allows writing plugins for custom real-time analysis - I have used the output of these to track custom pings but haven't set them up myself.

More info at https://wiki.mozilla.org/Telemetry and folks in #telemetry on irc.m.o have been very helpful for me in the past.
body_text:
More specifics on sampling and getting useful data out of redash:
The longitudinal dataset rolls a lot of things up for you (each row contains a unique client ID and all the rest of the data is present as arrays on each row) and makes this easier although due to the size of the data you still must take a sample. The larger problem is that it is only updated once per week.
To get data closer to real time, there is a main summary dataset that is updated more often (close to real-time IIRC), but as the data hasn't been rolled up as above it's a huge number of rows so you must take a very tiny sample to keep from melting the infra.
I have less experience with ATMO but my understanding is that you must write a map/reduce job or a Jupyter notebook and have that job run regularly.
There's also a tool called Hindsight that allows writing plugins for custom real-time analysis - I have used the output of these to track custom pings but haven't set them up myself.
More info at https://wiki.mozilla.org/Telemetry and folks in #telemetry on irc.m.o have been very helpful for me in the past.
body_html:
More specifics on sampling and getting useful data out of redash:

The longitudinal dataset rolls a lot of things up for you (each row contains a unique client ID and all the rest of the data is present as arrays on each row) and makes this easier although due to the size of the data you still must take a sample. The larger problem is that it is only updated once per week.

To get data closer to real time, there is a main summary dataset that is updated more often (close to real-time IIRC), but as the data hasn't been rolled up as above it's a huge number of rows so you must take a very tiny sample to keep from melting the infra.

I have less experience with ATMO but my understanding is that you must write a map/reduce job or a Jupyter notebook and have that job run regularly.

There's also a tool called Hindsight that allows writing plugins for custom real-time analysis - I have used the output of these to track custom pings but haven't set them up myself.

More info at https://wiki.mozilla.org/Telemetry and folks in #telemetry on irc.m.o have been very helpful for me in the past.
